overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second and fifth circuits and require the third circuit of the judiciary and big island drug court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. [3] [3] The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [3] [3] The Act shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3]
appropriations: The Act appropriates an unspecified sum out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027 to the judiciary for equipment, services, and temporary positions. [3] [3] It also appropriates an unspecified sum for the same fiscal years to the department of health for the women's court pilot program and the establishment of temporary positions. [3] The Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs respectfully requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Department of Health requests a budget of $801,802 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt), which is based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [2] The testimony indicates each circuit would require a 1.0 FTE Clinical Psychologist for $145,000 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt), a 1.0 FTE Social Worker/Human Services Professional IV for $76,788 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt), and a 1.0 FTE Social Services Assistant V for $45,216 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt). [2] The Judiciary proposed leveraging the existing Big Island Drug Court structure to supplement existing services as a possible approach for the Third Circuit. [2]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. [3] The third circuit of the judiciary and big island drug court shall conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. [3] The sums appropriated to the department of health shall be expended by the department of health for the purposes of this Act. [3]
economic_impact: The goal of the program is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [3] Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. [3] [3] As of August, 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the First Circuit's program, Mohala Wahine. [3]
policy_impact: This Act amends a measure that originally sought to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary. [4] Your Committee has amended this measure by deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and instead requiring the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to study and submit a report on establishing a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. [4] [4] The bill also inserts an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program, including the establishment of positions. [4] [4]
revenue_sources: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [3] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [3] A separate appropriation from general revenues is made to the department of health. [3]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Act appropriates unspecified funds for FY 2025-2026 and FY 2026-2027 and sunsets on June 30, 2028. [3] [3] The Committee on Finance is requested to consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4] This includes $145,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary clinical psychologist position; $76,788 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary social worker/human services professional IV position; and $45,216 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary social services assistant V position. [4] [4] The Department of Health's request for $801,802 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) is based on the staffing requirements for the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [2] An unspecified number of temporary staff positions are to be established in the Judiciary. [4] The judiciary is required to submit a report of its findings and recommendations prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028. [3] The third circuit of the judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation and resource requirements, to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026. [3]
operating_revenue_impact: This measure is not anticipated to impact operating revenues. [3] The program is funded by appropriations from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [3] No revenue-generating mechanisms are included in the bill. [3]
capital_expenditure_impact: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for equipment. [3] [3] The bill does not provide further details on the type or extent of equipment needed. [3] No other capital expenditures are mentioned. [3]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: This Act shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3] The judiciary shall submit a report with recommendations as to whether the women's court pilot program should continue as a pilot program, expand to include additional participants, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [3] Any fiscal implications after the repeal date would be contingent on future legislation. [3]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The scope of the measure has changed significantly; language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary has been deleted. [4] Instead, the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court are now required to study and submit a report on establishing such a program. [4] [4] An appropriation for the Department of Health has been inserted for the women's court pilot program, including the establishment of positions. [4] [4] A committee report specifies a requested appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health for one temporary clinical psychologist, one temporary social worker, and one temporary social services assistant.
